The Barbican Centre for Contemporary Art, London, has appointed Alison Black as the new artistic director of the Barbican, the region’s largest arts institution. Black will be responsible for leading the center’s London, Hong Kong, and South East locations in conjunction with the artist-run space Frieze.“Alison has been an indomitable voice in contemporary art for more than twenty years and is widely regarded as one of the most important and influential figures in the art world,” said Tim Whitley, chair of the Barbican’s board of trustees. “Her passion for the arts, her ability to support artists in their work, her commitment to building bridges between contemporary art museums and their audiences, and her ability to see art from a wide range of perspectives are among the reasons why we are so excited to welcome her to the Barbican.” In her new role, Black will have the responsibility of planning and executing the Barbican’s 2020 edition, which will take up the themes of resilience and technology, and will oversee programming that draws from artists’ and institutions’ collections and draws from her own practice. The City of London has revealed that it plans to overhaul the way that it allocates funding for artworks and cultural institutions through a new tax that will apply to all works of art and cultural heritage in the capital. The plan, which will be unveiled in a royal commission into the future of the City’s Endowment, will also introduce a new tax-free arts fund that will allow the UK’s museums and cultural sites to receive a one-time $2.5 billion subsidy that will support the design, construction, renovation, conservation, preservation, display, exhibition, or performance of art.“We are creating a new way of working for the future of art in the UK,” Catherine Beard, director of the National Portrait Gallery, told the Art Newspaper. “It is an exciting time to think about and redesign cities in new ways. This year’s Royal Commission into the Future of Art was an exciting period for museums and galleries, so we are working hard to think through how we will support the work of our galleries, museums and institutions as we continue to change how we live and work in the city.”
